reference.description: Reference should be a url, incident number, case ID, or other reference to the document the VERIS incident was based on.

summary.description:
Give a good descriptive summary of the incident in several sentences. Use natural language instead of VERIS notation, but we should be able to 'VERISize' the incident pretty well from just this description.
**REMINDER: IF THIS IS FOR THE DBIR AND NOT VCDB - DON'T RECORD VICTIM-INDENTIFYING INFO**

source_id.description: Source of the data (eg vcdb, vzir, hr dept)

campaign_id.description: (Way to associate multiple incident w/in one campaign).

incident.description: When did this incident initially occur?

compromise.description: How long from the first action to the first compromise of an attribute?

exfiltration.description: How long from initial compromise to first known data exfiltration?

discovery.description: How long from compromise until the incident was discovered by the victim organization?

containment.description: How long did it take the organization to contain the incident once it was discovered?

victim.description: More Info. **REMINDER - UNLESS THIS IS A VCDB INCIDENT, DON'T RECORD VICTIM-IDENTIFYING INFO IN ANY INCIDENT TO BE SUBMITTED TO THE DBIR**

employee_count.description: Number of employees.  Only use the count of the individual instance of a business (e.g. franchise location vs entire company) if the action vector was explicitly something unique to this individual instance. (i.e. This franchisee used a non-standard POS system that was then compromised.)

industry.description: Victim NAICS Code. You can look it up here or here.

government.description: The level of government if industry starts with 92.  Otherwise 'NA'

locations_affected.description: The number of victim locations, (stores, offices, etc), affected

region.description: The UN M.49 super-region and sub-region joined together. e.g. North America: 019021. South America (Brazil): 019005, Asia: 142000, East Asia (includes China): 142030, West Asia (Middle East): 142145, South Asia (India): 142034, Eastern Europe: 150151, Western Europe: 150155. Use 000000 if you do not know and 000001 for 'other' (includes international waters and outer space). If you only know the super-region, use zero's for the region. (e.g. 019000 for Americas.)

state.description: ALL CAPS. For US states, you can use the ISO_3166-2 2-character state code, otherwise use the full ISO_3166-2 Country subdivision code

notes.description: **UNLESS THIS IS FOR VCDB, DON'T RECORD VICTIM-INDENTIFYING INFO IF THIS WILL BE SUBMITTED TO THE DBIR**

secondary.description: Secondary victims indicates that the breach being coded is the first part of a supply chain breach.

amount.definition: The number of known secondary victims. Should always be a positive number if victim_id is filled in.  May not represent all victims if some are unknown.

victim_id.description: List any secondary victims here.  IF a NAICS is known, list the NAICS code after a semi-colon.  For example: `verizon;517911`.  If only the NAICS code is known, list it first.  `;517911`

revenue.description: For the DBIR, this is a low priority field and is OK to not fill in.

iso_currency_code.description: ISO4217 currency code. More Info

action.description: What threat actions were involved? More Info

hacking.description: Think things a person does at a keyboard (rather than by a program). More Info

result.description: The result of the action.  If there's a difference between action result and actor intent, use the result not intent.

malware.description: Think things a program does (rather than a person on a keyboard) More Info

result.description: The result of the action.  If there's a difference between action result and actor intent, use the result not intent.

name.description: Common name(s) or strain(s) of malware

social.description: Actions done to a person. More Info

result.description: The result of the action.  If there's a difference between action result and actor intent, use the result not intent.

misuse.description: Unapproved use of legitimate access or permissions. More Info

result.description: The result of the action.  If there's a difference between action result and actor intent, use the result not intent.

physical.description: Actions involving proximity and physical contact. More Info

result.description: The result of the action.  If there's a difference between action result and actor intent, use the result not intent.

environmental.description: Forces of nature. Cannot include intentional actions. More Info

result.description: The result of the action.  If there's a difference between action result and actor intent, use the result not intent.

actor.description: What entity did the threat action? More Info

external.description: Unaffiliated with the victim. More Info

region.description: The UN M.49 super-region and sub-region joined together. e.g. North America: 019021. South America (Brazil): 019005, Asia: 142000, East Asia (includes China): 142030, West Asia (Middle East): 142145, South Asia (India): 142034, Eastern Europe: 150151, Western Europe: 150155. Use 000000 if you do not know and 000001 for 'other' (includes international waters and outer space). If you only know the super-region, use zero's for the region. (e.g. 019000 for Americas.)

internal.description: The victim or a part thereof (such as an employee). More Info. Unless it is an error or intentional breaking of rules (misuse), the actor MUST be acting maliciously.

job_change.description: Recent job change PRIOR to incident? (i.e., not asking if 'let go' afterwards)

partner.description: An entity with an organizational relationship to the victim, but not the victim (such as a customer or supplier). More Info

region.description: The UN M.49 super-region and sub-region joined together. e.g. North America: 019021. South America (Brazil): 019005, Asia: 142000, East Asia (includes China): 142030, West Asia (Middle East): 142145, South Asia (India): 142034, Eastern Europe: 150151, Western Europe: 150155. Use 000000 if you do not know and 000001 for 'other' (includes international waters and outer space). If you only know the super-region, use zero's for the region. (e.g. 019000 for Americas.)

unknown.description: If the actor is unknown, you *must* add a note of some type, otherwise the incident will not validate.

asset.description: What assets were affected by the incident actions. Data types and record count will be covered in the attributes section. More Info

variety.description: What varieties of assets were compromised?

amount.description: How many total systems were compromised?

ownership.description: Who owns the affected asset? This can allow us to identify employee-owned (BYOD) assets.

cloud.description: Only answer if you know for sure if the asset was hosted in a cloud service.

hosting.description: Where is the affected asset hosted/located?

management.description: Independent of physical location, who administers and maintains the affected asset?

role.description: Is the asset Information Technology (IT) such as email or the domain controller or Operational Technology (OT) such as rail-switching computers for a railroad or manufacturing robots for a manufacturing company.

attribute.description: What attributes were compromised? More Info

confidentiality.description: Was data (potentially) disclosed to an unauthorized party? More Info

data_disclosure.description: Was data disclosed?  This is the core determiner if this incident is a breach.  If this is 'Yes', it will be considered a breach.  If it is anything else, it will only be an incident.

data.description: Varieties (and amount) of data compromised. Click the red ‘Add’ button to record multiple data varieties.

integrity.description: Was a person manipulated or the state of a system changed? More Info

availability.description: Was something rendered partially or wholly unavailable? More Info

duration.description: Specific value of the specific selected unit, (i.e., # of 'days').

result.description: The result of the action.  If there's a difference between action result and actor intent, use the result not intent.

targeted.description:
Was this a targeted or opportunistic attack? More Info
N/A: Not an attack (e.g., unintentional actions)
Opportunistic: Victim was NOT pre-selected as a target; they were identified/attacked because they exhibited a weakness the attacker knew how to exploit.
Targeted: The victim is pre-selected as a target; the attacker(s) then determined what weaknesses exist within the target that could be exploited.

discovery_method.description: What discovery method was involved? More Info

internal.description: Discovered by entity within the victim organization.

partner.description: Discovered by a partner of the victim.

discovery_notes.description: How was the incident discovered? More Info

value_chain.description: Capabilities and investments an attacker must acquire prior to the actions on target, (either by purchase or investment in creating).  May be internal to the actors organization (vertically integrated org), or external (purchased in a criminal market).

development.description: Software that must be developed to accomplish the actions on target.

non-distribution services.description: Services provided and used by malicious actors other than those used for distribution of actor content

targeting.description: Things that identify exploitable opportunities.  These overlap heavily with data varieties that are compromised.

distribution.description: Services used to distribute actor content.

cash-out.description: Methods for converting something (likely the attribute compromised) into currency.

money laundering.description: Methods for concealing the origins of illegally obtained money.

impact.description:
Impact Info
**REMINDER - UNLESS THIS IS FOR VCDB, DON'T RECORD VICTIM-INDENTIFYING INFO IF SUBMITTING TO THE DBIR**
**Tip: Hold CTRL or COMMAND to select multiple items from a list.

iso_currency_code.description: ISO4217 currency code. More Info

overall_amount.description: The total amount lost in the given ISO currency code.

overall_min_amount.description: When 'overall_amount' would be a range, use this field for the minimum of that range. Note: Values here will not appear in searches for 'overall_amount'.

overall_max_amount.description: When 'overall_amount' would be a range, use this field for the maximum of that range. Note: Values here will not appear in searches for 'overall_amount'.

loss.description: Were any losses or costs reported for this incident? (Definitions for loss varieties and ratings are here)

plus.description: Plus is the appropriate place to extend the VERIS schema for your own needs.  Add organization-specific enumerations here.

master_id.description: Master_id is a type 4 UUID and is unique for every record (incident).

sub_source.description: This field defines how the data was selected below the source level.  For example, It is a PHIDBR, record in VCDB, it should be 'phidbr'.  If it is a priority incident, it should be 'priority'.  If the incident is randomly assigned through vcdb assignment, it should be  'random' or blank.  It can be used by others to differentiate between different sources within their data.

analysis_status.description: In-progress (not yet complete) -> Ready for review (complete but not reviewed by DBIR team) -> First pass (One person has reviewed) -> Reviewed (Two people have reviewed) -> Finalized (Reviewed by single person reviewing all data)

analyst.description: Individual coding the incident. Please use a consistent format, like [first_initial][last_name] (e.g. asmith)

analyst_notes.description: Record notes about the analysis of the incident. (This is in contrast to notes about the incident itself which should go in 'notes'.)

data_abuse.description: The data was used for fraud, used mischievously, used maliciously, or otherwise abused.

github.description: Github issue #.  Only used in VCDB.

security_maturity.description: How would you rate the maturity of the victim's overall security program?

extra.description: Extra is a reserved name and should not appear in any objects. It should only be used for temporary derived columns during analysis.

corrective_action.description:
What corrective action(s) are planned (or recommended) to prevent and/or detect similar incidents in the future?
This can include general recommendations, specific changes to policy, procedures, personnel, and technology, short-term and long-term strategies, etc. Don't simply copy what the investigator said. Tie to the root causes listed above, and focus on practical, effective corrective actions.

control_failure.description:
What were the root control failures or weaknesses that allowed this incident to occur?
Obviously, there may be a multitude of factors that could be listed here. Include as many as you want, but focus on the issues most pertinent to why the incident occurred.

schema_version.description: Schema version in use. This should be 1.3.7 for this schema.

schema_name.description: Name of Schema.  This can be used to signal to software reading the schema which it is.  Common values are 'verisc', 'dbir', and 'vcdb'.
